6. The oversight process

To obtain a balanced view on the state of provincial tourism in the two provinces, the committee received provincial perspectives on tourism and visited various areas and attraction sites in Mpumalanga and Eastern Cape to ascertain the sate of tourism and the challenges experienced.
6.1 Oversight visit schedule

Table 2: Oversight visit schedule in Mpumalanga and Eastern Cape provinces | |Mpumalanga Province | | | | | | |Dates |Meeting Place |City | |4 June 2012 |Emnotweni Sun |Nelspruit | |5 June 2012 |MPTA Board Room |Nelspruit | |6 June 2012 |MRTT Hotel School |Nelspruit | |7 June 2012 |Canyon Nature Reserve |Nelspruit | |8 June 2012 |Skukuza Rest Camp |Kruger National Park | | | | |
6.2 Process
The process followed during the oversight visits included:

I. Briefing sessions held with provincial departments, district and local municipalities to outline the existing state of tourism, challenges and opportunities. II. Hearings held with tourism industry stakeholders. III. Site visits intended to obtain first-hand experience on prospects, opportunities and challenges by both provincial governments and the communities; and IV. Visits were concluded with stakeholder engagement sessions which sought to map out the plan of government as a collective from (local, district, provincial and national) on the issues raised by stakeholders.
7. Briefing sessions, stakeholder engagements and site visits
The process followed during the oversight visit in Mpumalanga included the following:
7.1 Welcome by Ms Clara Ndlovu, Deputy Chairperson of Mpumalanga Tourism and Parks Agency (MTPA) Board

I. The following main issues were highlighted during the address by the Deputy Chairperson of Mpumalanga Tourism and Parks Agency: II. Mpumalanga Province is one of the main destinations of choice for international arrivals, as confirmed by most recent statistics on international arrivals released by South African Tourism. III. The annual statistics place Mpumalanga at 3rd position after Gauteng and Western Cape, with a 15.8% share of international tourists. The MTPA was committed to multiply its efforts to revive the popularity of the province among domestic tourists and the Agency has supported hosting of vibrant sporting, musical and cultural events in the province. IV. The MTPA successfully marketed the province at the Tourism Indaba, which is regarded as a world class annual trade show where provinces showcase their products. V. In 2011, the MTPA launched the TRILAND Regional Tourism Brand together with Mozambique and Swaziland. Among others, the brand seeks to: promote, develop and position Mpumalanga together with Mozambique and Swaziland as a world-class regional tourism destination; contribute to the integration of the region; contribute to employment creation; develop sustainable tourism; participate in the conservation and protection of biodiversity; and preserve cultural values, heritage and national prides. VI. The MTPA endeavours to promote inclusive economic growth and facilitated the creation of 543 jobs through the Social Responsibility Programme projects for the period 1 April 2011 to 31 March 2012. VII. Jobs created were within the programme of Social Responsibility Projects at Songimvelo with (238 jobs), Blyde River Canyon (53 jobs) and Zithabiseni Resort with (252 jobs). VIII. A further 273 jobs were created through the Extended Public Works Programme. The Agency also facilitated training and placement of 75 tourism ambassadors at hotels, lodges, guest houses and tour operators. Also non-financial support service was provided to 45 SMMEs.
7.2 Mpumalanga Tourism and Parks Agency (MTPA)

I. The following main issues were highlighted during the address by the Acting Chief Executive Officer: II. Mpumalanga Tourism and Parks Agency is established in terms of the MPTA Act No. 5 of 2005. Section 3 of the Act states that the objects of the Agency shall be to provide for the sustainable management and promotion of tourism and nature conservation in the province and to ensure the sustainable utilization of natural resources. III. Schedule 4 of the Constitution of the Republic of South Africa refers to the functional areas of concurrent national and provincial legislative competence. IV. It is generally recognised that the tourism industry has the potential of being a catalyst for significant economic growth and development with the Province of Mpumalanga. V. It is a priority of the provincial government to develop the tourism sector within the province in a sustainable and acceptable manner to ensure that the development of the potential of tourism sector will significantly contribute to economic growth and development in order to improve the quality of life of the inhabitant of the province. VI. Everyone has the right to have the environment protected, through reasonable legislative and other measures that promotes conservation and secures ecologically sustainable development and the use of natural resources while promoting justifiable economic and social development. VII. The development of tourism industry will increase entrepreneurial and employment opportunities in the industry and specifically contribute to the development opportunities for previously disadvantaged individuals and communities. VIII. The conservation management of natural resources will increase employment opportunities and specifically contribute to the development opportunities and broadening of participation in conservation management by previously disadvantaged. IX. Conservation management of the natural resources will contribute to, and enhance the uniqueness of the province as a tourist destination.
Mandate of the Mpumalanga Tourism Parks Agency is the:

I. Management and conservation of biodiversity and ecosystem within the province. II. Management of protected areas. III. Development and marketing of tourism; and IV. Promotion and creation of socio-economic growth and transformation within the tourism and conservation industry.
3. Department of Economic Development, Environment and Tourism
7.3.1 Summary of the presentation

I. The provincial GDP grew at 3.1 percent and the expected rate for 2011 is equal to the national growth rate. II. Mpumalangas percentage share of the national population of 50.59 million was 7.2 percent, or 3.66 million in 2011. III. In total over the last year, Mpumalanga recorded 47 000 and 37 000 new jobs in 2011 quarter 4 and 2012 quarter 1 respectively, year on- year basis. IV. In 2010, the three largest contributors to the provincial economy were manufacturing with (20.6 per cent), mining with 18.8 per cent) and community services with (16.0 per cent). V. In 2010, poverty rate was 45.6 per cent or 1.72 million of citizens that lived in households with an income less than the poverty income. The unemployment rate was 27.7 per cent in 2011 quarter 4 and 30.3 in 2012 first quarter. VI. The provincial income distribution became more unequal between 1996 and 2009, however, the Gini-coefficient improved somewhat to 0.64 in 2010. VII. A major share of households (46.9 percent) in the province earned less than R42 000 per year (R3 500 per month) in 2010. VIII. The contribution to the national economy was the joint fifth largest with a share of 6.4 percent in 2010. IX. In March 2012, inflation measurement in the province of 6.6 percent was higher than the national level of 6.0 percent and higher than the upper band of the inflation target range.

7.3.2 Economic Growth and Development Path targets for 2020 a) Unemployment I. Reduce the unemployment rate to 15 percent by 2020. II. Creating 720 000 new jobs. III. This is a 14 percent decrease from the 2010 provincial unemployment rate of 29 percent.

b) Inequality I. Reduce inequality by enhancing the skills set of the labour force, fixed capital investment and improvements in education. II. Government will involve the private sector in planning and skills development as the private sector will be the engine of the creation.

c) Poverty I. Reduce the poverty rate from the 2009 level of 47.8 percent to 25 percent by 2020. II. Focus will be on job creation through public works programmes, employment guarantee schemes, education and skills attainment.
d) Key challenges to be addressed:

I. High unemployment rate at 30.3 percent in the first quarter of 2012. II. Production focused in sunset industries with no beneficiation; III. HIV and Aids, ailing agricultural sector, value from manufacturing, infrastructure & service delivery, skills shortages and environmental concerns; and IV. The National Tourism Month is expected to be launched in Mpumalanga in September 2012, but due to funding, the province may loose the hosting of the event.
7.3.3 2012/13 Budget performance and programmes

I. Programme 1 (Administration) has decrease from R99 416 million because: bursaries and security functions have moved to safety and education respectively. II. Programme 2 (Integrated Economic Development). The programme allocation has increased from R168 219 million to R228 162 million because: Mega was allocated an extra amount R60 million for infrastructure. III. Programme 3 (Trade and Sector Development) has increased from R298 536 million to R300 628 million because: Mpumalanga Tourism and Parks Agency was allocated an extra amount of R50 606 million for infrastructure upgrading in the Parks. IV. Programme 4 (Business Regulations) allocation has increased from R58 694 million to R60 560 million because: Mpumalanga Gambling Board increase from R39 908 million to R41 908 million. V. Programme 5 (Economic Planning) the allocation has decrease from R9 178 million to R8 840 million because the department did not budget for the Chief Directors position and Directors for Monitoring and Evaluation and Development. VI. Programme 6 (Environmental Services) allocation has increased from R68 801 million to R72 945 million because the Mpumalanga Air Quality Monitoring station and Central waste management contracts which the department has entered into.
7.3.4 Findings

I. The calculation indicates that bulk of the budget (67 percent) is transferred to public entities, such as MEGA 27 percent, MTPA 33 percent, MGB 5percent and Zithabiseni Resort 2 percent; and II. The Provincial Department received only 33 percent of the total budget distribution.
4. Zithabiseni Resort
7.4.1 Historical background

I. The Zithabiseni Resort facility was developed in the late 1960 around a hot spring which was used by the Afrikaans community for informal gatherings over weekends. Due to its location on the picturesque ridge it was known as Die Bron. In 1986 the Transvaal Provincial Administration handed it over to the then Kwa-Ndebele government which renamed the facility, Zithabiseni meaning a place for pleasure and leisure. II. The resort was taken over by the Mpumalanga Provincial Government after the 1994 democratic election and the demarcation of the country. Within the Mpumalanga provincial government the management and control of the resort moved through a series of ownerships from the Mpumalanga Parks Board to the Department of Agriculture, then to the Department of Environmental Affairs and Tourism and finally rested with the Department for Economic Development, Environment and Tourism. III. In 2001, the Department of Economic Affairs and Finance attempted to offload the resort through a commercialization processes and the facility was put up for sale, but without success as a buyer or investor or could not be found.
7.4.2 State of the resort before intervention

I. The resort was in a state of collapse when the department intervened and appointed a new General Manager in 2010. An assignment to conduct policy business and policy review of Zithabiseni was done during the period of November to December 2010. II. The state of water pipe was not in good condition, asbestos pipes were used. The resort main entrance was unattractive. III. The state of workers was in disarray. The number of chalets that were functional was 45. The internal road was in a bad condition. The TV network signal was not functional including the TV sets which were outdated. The general appearance of the resort was not up to the expected standard. IV. In the financial year 2009/2011 the National Department of Tourism commissioned an amount of R30 million for the upgrade of chalets, internal roads and main entrance. V. The resort is sustained by the grant amounts received on yearly basis from the Mpumalanga Department of Economic Development, Environment and Tourism. VI. The Audit conducted for the year ended 31 March 2008, revealed plethora of challenges related to systems of internal control and good governance. The audit report made recommendations for the establishment and implementation of measures that will address the challenges. VII. A further forensic audit was conducted for the year ended 31 March 2009, and is in the possession of the Department. The report has been received by the resort and the necessary disciplinary steps had been taken.
7.4.3 Achievements

I. The resort concluded a strategic planning wherein both strategic plan and business plan were finalised and new organisational structures were concluded. II. Renovations are almost complete for the first phase and appointments of four departmental managers concluded. III. Human resource policies developed and workshop of the policies are planned. Financial policies also developed to aid the internal control measures. The resort is currently busy with the restructuring of staff. IV. New equipment were purchased for the chalets such as linen, TV sets and others. V. The resort has also developed the marketing plan and renovated 20 chalets, bring the number of functional chalets to 75, this was done from the National Department of Tourism funding. VI. The main gate has been renovated and looks appealing to tourists. The water pipes have been upgraded from asbestos to pvc standard, and the water standard is satisfactory. VII. The internal road has been upgraded by the construction of the pavement from NDT funding. The TV signal has improved. VIII. New TV sets have been procured for all the rooms that are operational and new three transport vehicles were also procured for the effective functioning of the resort.
7.4.4 Challenges

I. Lack of funding to develop the access road. II. Lack of skilled personnel. III. Proper registration of the entity. IV. Lack of funding for upgrading of the purification plant and to install a high level mast light. V. Funding for marketing the resort.
5. Mpumalanga Regional Training Trust (MRTT)
7.5.1 Mpumalanga Regional Training Trust

I. Mpumalanga Regional Training Trust was established in 1993 and registered as a Section 21 of Company as a non profit organization, according to the Companies Act (Act No. 61 of 1973) and listed as Schedule 3C of the Public Finance Management Act of 1999. II. MRTT is established as Hospitality and Tourism Academy located between Nelspruit and Ka-Nyamazane in 2005. The Academy contributes towards the development of hospitality and tourism sector within the Mpumalanga province. III. The MRTT reports directly to Mpumalanga Department of Education through a Board of Directors. IV. MRTT is mandated to develop the human resource base of the Mpumalanga Province through the provision of experiential, practical, technical, hospitality, tourism, entrepreneurial and life skills training. V. The main focus is to empower learners, primarily the disadvantaged communities especially the youth, industry workers and government employees, to participate in the broader economic sphere of the province and beyond. VI. It also provides quality customised training interventions, practical workplace training, placement and after-care according to the demands of the market for job creation and poverty alleviation.
7.5.2 Accredited programme offerings
I. Food and Beverages (NQF level 4). II. Professional Cookery (NQF level 4). III. Accommodation services(NQF level 2) IV. Assistant Chef (NQF Level 2).
7.5.3 Training Model for MRTT
Utilisation of an integrated approach to the training as follows:

I. Provision of theoretical knowledge base through classroom contact. II. Practical skills training; and III. Workplace training under supervision by qualified workplace mentors and coaches for further skills acquisition within 3 star graded facility in-house.
7.5.4 Challenges facing the Academy
I. Funding of training for learners. II. Funding for programme development. III. Funding for infrastructure development; and IV. Funding for HR capacity building.
6. Mpumalanga Economic Growth Agency (MEGA)
7.6.1 Mpumalanga Economic Growth Agency
The Agency is established to:

I. Provide funding in respect of property development including the granting of housing loans. II. Provide funding in respect of approved enterprises and agricultural development focusing primarily on previously disadvantaged individuals within the province. III. Focusing on project management, development and management of immovable property. IV. Promote foreign trade and investment to ensure enterprise and agricultural development will significantly contribute to economic growth and development, with specific emphasis on Black Economic Empowerment.
The following key strategic programmes exist:
I. Development finance II. Trade and Investment promotion; and III. Property infrastructure development / management.
MEGA achievements on Trade and Investment Promotion
I. Facilitated R346 million direct investment. II. Facilitated R68.3 million exports by emerging exporters; and III. The Agency has created 330 new jobs.
Extended mandate
In addition, to provide integrated economic growth solutions in support of sustainable development for a better life for all in citizens of the province:

I. MEGA has received the mandate to provide bulk water and sanitation infrastructure and will partner on behalf of government with the private sector in facilitating and implementing the required infrastructure programmes. II. It is envisaged the project will also create opportunities for SMMEs and additional job creation; and III. Create a more conducive environment for tourism development.
Site visits
The committee visited the following sites:
7. Site visit to the Matopos Lodge

7.7.1 Findings I. Matopos Lodge is naturally beautiful and has the good view of Nelspruit. II. The conference facility can cater up to 60 people. III. The outpost-lodge is situated just 4 kilometres from the central business district. 7.7.2 Service offerings I. Accommodation II. Catering III. Conferencing; and IV. Private weddings

7.7.3 Challenges I. The establishment is not graded and the Mr Mdluli indicated the person who used to assist is no longer working for the Tourism Grading Council. II. There was no funding assistance available from the government. The business was acquired through the bank loan.
8. Site visit to The Nutting Guest House
7.8.1 Findings

I. The Nutting House owns a 7.1 hectare property situated in the picturesque hills at Burnside, in close proximity to the N4 highway and 10 kilometres from Nelspruit. II. The business can accommodate 900 people. III. On the property the owner operates a luxury guest house, a conference centre and wedding facility; and also farms with macadamia nuts.
7.8.2 Facilities include

I. 12 large bedrooms (each with its own en-suite complete bathroom and own outside entrance). II. Large kitchen, a dinning room and conference facility. III. 70 square meter thatched lapa next to the dinning room. IV. A swimming pool, a sauna, a very large landscaped garden and secure parking.
7.8.3 Challenges

I. Ms Shongwe indicated that although the business is graded, the B&B is a 3 star accommodation and the conference facility is a 4 star, she did not receive any government grant. II. The Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) assistance programme was approached for assistance but did not succeed. III. The business on the government database, but getting business from this database is seldom.
9. Site visit to the Sidwala Caves

I. The Sidwala Caves, located off the R539 west of the Mobombela, feature lengthy passages with some dramatic formations. II. Displays showing details of early occupations are added attraction. III. The Caves are situated in pre-cumbrian dolomites formed over 3000 million years ago. IV. In terms of the pre-history the caves were mainly used as shelter during bad weather. Excavations are still in progress and have thus far yielded a collection of stone-age tools which are on display at the cave entrance; and V. According to modern history, in the nineteenth century these caves were used by Samcuba, a relative of the Swazi King, as a fortress. In the power struggle for the throne, many battles were fought at the cave entrance.
10. Site visit to the MRTT Hotel School
7.10.1 Findings

I. The hospitality academy offers hospitality and tourism programmes accredited by the Tourism, Hospitality & Sport Education & Training Authority (THETA) seta and runs at full capacity with 130 full-time learners per annum. II. It has the capacity to accommodate another 40 learners in short skills programmes offered in Assistant Chef, Bar attendance and Cooking convenience food. III. The hotel school is connected to a functional 3 star hotel that offers accommodation, conferencing and restaurant facilities where learners undergo relevant experiential training.
7.10.2 Programme offerings
Programmes offered are accredited by the THETA SETA and includes the following:

I. National Certificate in Food and Beverage Services NQF Level 4 one year. II. National Certificate in Professional Cookery NQF Level 4 one year. III. National Certificate in Accommodation Services NQF Level 2 three months. IV. Skills Programme in Hotel Receptionist NQF Level 2 three months. V. Short programme in Assistant Chef NQF Level 2 three months. VI. Skills Programme in Cook Convenience Food NQF Level 2 three months; and VII. Skills programme in Bar Attendance NQF Level 2 three months.

7.10.3 Pre-admission assessment I. The pre-admission assessment is to determine levels of existing knowledge related to the chosen area of study and to identify gaps for learner development (plans input). II. The assessments comprise of multiple choice questions assessing level of basic mathematical calculations, their familiarity with specific areas of hospitality and learners level of wellness of in their environment. III. The second part of the assessment comprises of English Language proficiency exercises to determine the learners level of understanding and writing.
7.10.4 Pre-admission Interviews

I. These are conducted to determine candidates understanding of selected programme, expectations of programme outcomes and level of interest in the Hospitality and Tourism Industry; and II. The interview is also used to establish learners interests, strengths, weaknesses and suitability to the chosen area of training in hospitality.
7.10.5 Industrial attachment
I. On completion of on-site training learners are placed on industrial attachment or experiential training for 3 to 6 months; and depending on the requirements of establishments.
11. Site visit to the Blyde River Canyon Nature Reserve

I. It is reported that Mpumalanga has more scenic waterfalls than any other Province and these are generally found across the escarpment and along the Panorama route. II. The Blyde River canyon is the largest green canyon in Africa. III. View sites overlooking the Blydepoort dam, the canyon and the Three Rondavels are signposted from the R532 north of Granskop; and IV. This is one of South Africas prime tourism sites.
7.12 Site visit to the Kruger National Park Conference Centre
Mr Peter Dlamini, Hospitality Services Manager of Skukuza Rest Camp took the committee through the orientation:

I. Skukuza Rest Camp is the largest in the park and is situated in the southern part of the park on the bank of the Sabie River. II. The Camp has two conference facilities, the Goldfields Auditorium and Nombolo Mdhluli conference centre. III. The conference has been built as part of SANParks commercialisation strategy which was adopted in 2001 and which also included the need to diversify the product offering. The main target market for the conference centre is the business sector. IV. The state of art facility consists of a main hall and four breakaway rooms offers for up to 500 people. V. The conference centre as a whole is named after Corporal Nombolo Mdhluli who served the Kruger National Park during the period from 1919 until his retirement in 1958. VI. The Main Hall and the four breakaway rooms are named after the Big 5. Ndlopfu (main hall), Ingwe (room 2), Ndau (room 3), Mhelembe (room 3) and Nari (room 4). The breakaway rooms are all the same size and two of the breakaway rooms can be joined together and used as one venue. 8. Findings / Observations
The Committee made the following observations during the oversight:

I. Rural tourism development remains a challenge. Government departments should tailor responses to this challenge in terms of programmes and budgets to address disparities and in an aligned programme to optimise actions that would cushion the vulnerable groups.

II. To ensure that the current EPWP Programmes are sustainable, they should be closely monitored and evaluated. This would assist in addressing concerns raised by the Auditor General in the 2010/11 financial year; including the difficulties of obtaining information specifically the statistics on the number of jobs created and the effectiveness or impact of the EPWP projects run by Department of Tourism on behalf of the communities.
III. There is no overlap of roles where the marketing of tourism locally and internationally is concerned.
IV. The support the different enterprises receive from the Department and how many of these enterprises actually yield positive results from this support is not clearly demonstrated.

V. Refocus on heritage and cultural heritage projects there was a greater need for investment towards cultural and heritage tourism. Heritage and cultural sites should be kept at an acceptable tourism level. The refocus on such sites would benefit poor rural communities.

VI. The importance of tourist road signage is often underestimated. Local government tourist road signage is extremely limited. It is also difficult to understand many of the historical sites of the township without a guide given the lack of interpretive boards.
VII. There is an often breakdown in communication between local, provincial and national spheres with regards to the permissions and standards in tourism signage.

VIII. The linkages both ways on tourism related issues between national, provincial and local spheres are weak. There needs to be improved working relationships on tourism-related issues between municipalities and regional stakeholders through collaborative alliances.

IX. There is a need for a defined tourism support package (resources, funding and capacity) to support local government. Resources to assist and direct investment at local government to realise tourism opportunities. A knowledge and exchange platform to highlight best practice case studies from other municipalities to encourage peer-to- peer learning.

X. Tourism features very low on the priority outputs of the local municipalities due to priority needs such as water, electricity, infrastructure, housing sport and recreation. As a result, municipalities regard tourism as an unfunded mandate placed on local government.

XI. The current lack of specific budget allocation towards the development of tourism at local government level is a challenge and results in low impact projects, unsustainable initiatives, and wish lists instead of action plans.
9. Recommendations Based on the stakeholder engagements, submissions by provincial authorities and site visits and the common challenges identified, the committee recommends as follows:

I. Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs): The Department should double its efforts by ensuring that the notion of private-public partnerships is a well endorsed practice for building capacity to delivery in the tourism and hospitality sectors.

II. Small, Medium and Micro Enterprises (SMMEs): All spheres of government should work towards strengthening competitiveness and promotion of SMMEs and cooperatives as they remain the cornerstone for growth of the economy and creation of work opportunities within the tourism and hospitality sectors.
III. The Department needs to facilitate market access and entry into the value chain by small businesses and cooperatives and reduce regulatory burden on small businesses.

IV. Local Government: The local sphere of government is an important contributor to the success of tourism activities in terms of community driven tourism philosophy. The efforts should be coordinated within the provincial tourism growth strategy.

V. Job creation at local level: tourism is a demand-driven sector. Therefore the volume and value of demand inform investment in supply and job creation. Provision of public infrastructure supporting local economic development is improved. This will assist municipalities to focus Local Economic Development initiatives that are skills creating, employment generating and domestic production and consumption promoting.

VI. Signage and road infrastructure: poor road signage and infrastructure impact negatively on access to tourism products, especially in rural areas. The co-operative work between the Department of Tourism and the Department of Transport to be intensified.
VII. Tourism information: Public education, awareness and information dissemination should be linked to outreach initiatives of the Department.
VIII. Synergic linkages should be developed and harnessed at all spheres of government so as to promote local tourism activities and strategic partnerships.

IX. Transformation of the tourism sector: There should greater action taken to support and implement Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment (BBBEE) as well as procurement policy implemented to achieve the BBEEE imperatives of government.

X. Air Lift Strategy: Aligning air transport with other national strategies through the common criteria of the national interest through interdepartmental participation with regards to National Foreign Policy, National Trade and Industry Strategy as well as general infrastructure requirements of South Africa. Reduced total cost of travel to South Africa should be the central focus of the strategy. XI. Skills Development: while the committee acknowledges the initiatives taken by the department to engage five universities in the country to develop skills and capacity the industry, there is also a need to support FET colleges and Sector Education and Training Authorities to be linked to business, industry and other advanced education and training programmes.

XII. Cost of air travel: Travel by air to Eastern Cape and Mpumalanga provinces is too expensive. There is a need for national government to assist to increase number of flights and reduce cost of flights.

XIII. Implementation of infrastructure development: Parliament should prioritise overseeing the implementation of infrastructure development aligned to rural communities and also ascertain support facilities in rural areas for tourism sector.

XIV. Extended Public Works Programme: There should be greater focus on monitoring the outputs and outcomes of Extended Public Work Programmes as it holds potential for poverty relief and providing first level skills and opportunity for productive citizenry.
10. Appreciation

The committee would like to extend the special appreciation to MEC in the Province, the Executive Mayors, Provincial Head of Department, municipal managers, project managers and all the officials who provided support throughout the provincial oversight trip.

11. Conclusion Education and training remains a critical element for the development and growth of tourism in the provinces. Although the current state of tourism in the Province is not completely satisfactory, there is a huge potential for the Province to advance in the tourism sector. However, for this to happen, there is a need for the tourism budget allocation in the Province to be increased to allow for this potential to be unlocked. This will significantly increase the contribution of tourism to job creation and sustainable livelihoods, as part of the key national priorities of Government. Report to be considered.

debateSection.p: The Committee having undertaken oversight visit to Eastern, Western and Central Regions from 18-22 June 2012, reports as follows:
1. Introduction
In support of the national effort for development and as part of assessing the state of tourism in the Provinces, the Committee visited the Western, Eastern and Central Regions of the Eastern Cape.

Tourism has been prioritised by the Provincial Government as one of the economic sectors that contribute to the countrys gross domestic product (GDP), create employment and mitigate the impact of poverty. This is in line with the current policy imperatives of the New Growth Path and the Industrial Policy Action Plan (IPAP 2). Sustainable and responsible tourism development has a triple effect in terms of social, economic and environmental benefits. The committee is mandated to conduct oversight in an effort to extract optimum benefits for the country from the resources and capacities available to the three spheres of government. The Committee felt that it was necessary to undertake a provincial oversight visit to Eastern Cape Province in 2012 to assess achievements of the sector and evaluate the nature of challenges, prospects for inclusive growth particularly in the rural areas and the extent of government support at all levels.
2. National priorities In line with national priorities relevant to the developmental agenda relating to the tourism sector, the committee identified the following:

2.1 Inclusive growth that creates jobs and promotes sustainable livelihoods with meaningful participation of the historically disadvantaged communities and individuals. 2.2 Involvement of rural communities in tourism growth and development in the mainstream industry. 2.3 Assess the skills development in the industry. Impact of crime in the industry and the response thereto.
3. Objectives of the visit

The Tourism White Paper spells out the functions of national government as establishing and facilitating enabling and appropriate legal and fiscal frameworks for the tourism industry and facilitating the sustainable and responsible development of the industry, by formulating developmental guidelines and regulatory measures. The objectives of the oversight visit, included:

3.1 To enhance cooperation and coordination between all spheres of government in developing and managing tourism. 3.2 To promote for growth and development of the tourism sector. 3.3 To promote quality tourism products and services 3.4 To assess the level of stakeholder participation both in the public and private sectors. 3.5 To assess support for cultural and heritage tourism growth. 3.6 To assess the implementation of the Extended Public Works (EPWP) and its outputs and outcomes. 3.7 To assess for the support for sustainable livelihoods with regards to small, medium and micro enterprises (SMMEs), cooperatives and individuals; and 3.8 To enhance and promote responsible tourism for the benefit of South Africa and the enjoyment of all its citizens and foreign visitors.
4. Delegation

5. The oversight visit schedule

Table 2: Oversight visit schedule in the Eastern Cape Province | |Eastern Cape Province | | | | | | |18 June 2012 |Isango Gate Guest House |Port Elizabeth | |19 June 2012 |Storms River Valley |Tsitsikama | |20 June 2012 |MyPond Hotel |Port Alfred | |21 June 2012 |Crawford Cabins |East London | |22 June 2012 |Cascades Hotel |East London | | | | |
6. Briefing sessions, stakeholder engagements and site visits
The process followed during the oversight visit in Eastern Cape included the following:
6.1 Eastern Cape Parks and Tourism Agency (ECPTA)
6.1.1 Briefing by the Chief Executive Officer

I. Poverty zones in the Eastern Cape indicate the spatial focus and potential impact zones for socio-economic interventions. As most of the income for Parks come from local market it is assumed that spending comes from the economic power zones in the province.

II. Financial consideration was a key driver in the drafting of the ECPTA business case. Precedence has set by mergers completed in other Provinces where merged entities outperformed non-merged entities.

III. Of concern was the apparent correlation between increase in the government grant and the decrease in revenue. This dependency on grants created the perception that as the size of the government grant increase, the drive, commitment and incentives towards securing own revenue decreased.

IV. The primary goal of the ECPTA is to ensure stakeholder and shareholder confidence. From a strategic level, this requires the achievement of the core elements of the business case, which is the primary focus of the shareholder and the Board.

V. ECPTA Act No. 2 of 2010 took effect on 1 July 2010 and confers powers and duties to ECPTA to manage protected areas and develop and facilitate tourism; and establish Eastern Cape Tourism Development Fund amongst others.

VI. Eastern Cape Tourism Development Fund aims to empower disadvantaged individuals in the tourism sector and may consist of percentage funding appropriated to ECPTA, donations, provincial tourism levy and any other funding.
VII. The ECPTA is currently in phase two of the three phase broad phases to ensure effective and efficient operational execution (merger consolidation, expansion and consolidation).
VIII. In terms of marketing and geographic spread, the province has 109 projects ranging from the infrastructure, tourism, conservation and reserves.

IX. Inter-governmental relations in the tourism industry had been included as a key performance area in the annual performance plan of the ECPTA. Some of the results include: integrated approach to fasttracking the development of tourism infrastructure with the support and commitment of R95 million from Department of Economic Development, Environment and Tourism (DEDEAT). The R30 million commitment from the DEDEAT for the hosting of key iconic events in the Province. In this regard African Open has yielded R150 million on a R9 million investment.

X. In terms of its strategic and operational plan the ECPTA will create 2 276 jobs in relation to its direct operations. This excludes the construction jobs that the R95 million infrastructure commitment will yield. The planned jobs per financial year detailed as follows: 2012/13 (423 jobs), 2013/14 (913 jobs), and 2014/15 (940 jobs).

XI. Through relations with the industry, ECPTA ensured placement of all 39 Chefs and 24 tourism buddies in both the private and the public sector. The mentorship programme has contributed to creation of 229 jobs in the sector between 2009 to 2011financial years. Created 10 SMME opportunities during the reserve upgrade process; and created 40 temporal job opportunities during the reserve upgrade.

XII. In response to the Provincial Tourism Master Plan and National Tourism Sector Strategy, ECPTA has prioritised skills development for the industry. The Agency has partnered with the Eastern Cape Development Cooperation and Tourism Enterprise Partnership for skills development. The programme also facilitated linkages and partnerships for the participants resulting to increased revenues and business contracts.

XIII. In order to negate the culture of poor service in the tourism industry and related sectors, the ECPTA implemented and supported the: ETEYA National Awards, Welcome Awards, Adventure Tourism & Conservation Awards; and Service Excellence seminars. The Agency created platforms for international and national market access for 60 tourism products; and further supported grading of about 300 accommodation establishments in the past three years.

XIV. To promote cultural and natural diversity the Agency initiated and supported various provincial events such as: Isingqi Sethu Festival; Grahamstown Arts Festival; Africa Open Golf Tournament; Buyelekhaya Music Festival; Wild Coast Jikeleza; and Rose Garden Festival and others. In order to ensure sustainability of events more funding is required.

XV. Redesigned the Provincial Tourism Forum as an active platform to engage with stakeholders and also established in-house capacity through Stewardship programme and People and Parks mechanisms directly engage with stakeholders. Launched new Coastal Route in partnership with the industry. 6.1.2 Challenges highlighted

I. The country needs to implement the Airlift Strategy for ECPTA. The Province needs the National Department of Tourism to assist in increasing the number of flights into the Eastern Cape and at the same time reduce cost of flights. First prize would be direct international flights that would allow international tour operators to fly directly to the Eastern Cape.

II. The revenue from the SA Tourism levies should be proportionally allocated to the tourism routes and Province so that it can be applied directly to the benefit of the province where it was generated.
III. The lead time for obtaining provincial statistics from SA Tourism is too long and reduces the ability of tourism managers to measure and manage the industry.
IV. Additional support is required to support interventions such as the Home of the Legends from a national tourism perspective.

V. Additional financial resources required to enable the ten provincial routes to be able to host at least one iconic event per year in each route. Iconic events generated exceptional returns on investment.
VI. Need technical assistance via Department of Trade and Industry and Tourism to cluster the Eastern Cape Tourism Industry to increase its effectiveness and efficiency.
VII. National Treasury to create mechanism that would allow for faster commercialisation of Provincial tourism assets in support of BBBEE.
2. Tsitsikama Tourism Stakeholder engagement session
6.2.1 Briefing by Mr Peter Myles: Private Sector

I. Market researchers try to gather information about customers perceptions and attitudes on a whole variety of subjects, from particular products and brands, to government policy and even their hopes for the future. II. This information can then be used to design products and services that meet customers needs or to design marketing campaigns that communicate effectively with a products target market. III. Market research is the systematic collection of information about supply and demand in tourism to guide the formulation of policies, strategies and plans for those concerned with the management of tourism interests, including government. IV. Eastern Cape tourism competitor analysis shows the province is the fifth in terms of 2007 and 2008 bed night statistics with 3.9 million and 3.8 million respectively. V. Overnight stays is the measurement of tourism performance, and in 2009 the Province had a share of 3.1 million for the year. VI. In 2011, the Eastern Cape provincial distribution in terms of bed night was 3.3 million with 3.7 percent being foreign arrivals. This is in contrast with 2004, when bed night was 3.4 million with 7.5 percent being foreign arrivals. VII. The Eastern Cape Province is third largest domestic tourism market in South Africa.
6.2.2 Challenges highlighted the private sector There is a need for local tourism statistics

I. There are no published tourism statistics for cities and towns in South Africa. II. The only local statistics available are when cities and towns start collecting their own data from the accommodation providers. III. However, this is a difficult task because accommodation providers are reluctant to share their guest information and occupancy rates with other service providers; and IV. It is worth investigating if raw data is available from Statistics South Africa.
6.3 Port Alfred Tourism Stakeholder engagement session
6.3.1 Briefing by Sunshine Coast Tourism in partnership with Ndlambe Municipality

I. Sunshine Coast Tourism and Ndlambe Municipality have entered into a partnership and signed Service Level Agreement and have fully constituted guiding constitution. II. Ndlambe Municipality is constituted by Port Alfred (Tourism Business Forum), Kenton (Tourism and Chamber of Business), Alexandria (Canon Rocks) and Bathurst / Kleinemonde. III. Sunshine Coast Tourism monthly reports are submitted timeously to Ndlambe Municipality and monthly reporting on performance available as open documents on Council Agenda. IV. SCT has removed past negative perceptions of tourism in Ndlambe. Tourism speaks as one body instead of 2 fragmented tourism offices and a Municipality body. Buy-in has been secured from Port Alfred Business Forum and Bushmans Chamber of Business. V. Created a dynamic website reflecting the richness and diversity of Ndlambe as a whole; and also created a professional, integrated and transformed tourism body. VI. There is a strong networking base with members and informative monthly newsletter is released. VII. Constantly adding new products to existing experiences and membership is keptto-date with local and international tourism trends. VIII. Promote route identification and expanding base of international tourism and awareness of the Eastern Cape and Ndlambe. IX. Weekly tourism information is submitted to local and regional newspapers; and monthly newsletters are sent out to a database of over 800 people nationally and internationally; and X. Expedition Africa International Adventure Race has been brought to Ndlambe Municipality.
6.3.2 Local challenges

I. Need funding to produce and develop new promotional material. II. Attend trade shows and grow the awareness of the product. III. Expand awareness within the area with more Information Centres; and IV. Create new products to draw visitors to Ndlambe area. 6.3.3 Provincial challenges
I. Self drive tours through the road system. II. Inadequate service III. Lack of transport; and IV. Communication in remote areas.
4. Site visit to Stenden University
Dr. Wouter Hensens: Academic Dean and General Manager briefed the committee as follows:
6.4.1 Course offerings

I. Stenden South Africa is a private higher education institution uniquely offering a 3 year Bachelor of Commerce Degree in Hospitality Management and is a satellite campus of Stenden University of Applied Science in Leeuwarden, the Netherlands. II. Other satellite campuses are in Thailand (Bangkok), Indonesia (Bali) and Qatar (Doha). III. The B. Com Hospitality Management incorporates various management disciplines and covers subjects such as Services, Marketing, Operations Management, Human Resource Management, Hospitality Law Fiancial Management and Accounting, Research, Revenue Management and General Management. IV. Both local and international students are encouraged to participate in Community Development Programmes, and use their personal and professional skills for the improvement of individuals living in communities in and around Port Alfred. V. Students can obtain a double degree by studying at Stenden University of Applied Sciences in The Netherlands for duration of one year. They will then graduate with a B Com from Stenden South Africa and a BBA International Hospitality Management (professional degree) are: Event Management, Heritage Tourism, Adventure Tourism, Entrepreneurship, Cruise Management, and Interior Design.
6.4.2 Problem Based Learning

I. A unique learning technique used is Problem Based Learning (PBL). Students are staked with solving a carefully chosen real life industry- related problem. II. Individually researched solutions are presented to the group under the guidance of a lecturer. III. Groups are small, usually 15 students, allowing a more personal learning experience. IV. My Pond Hotel is managed by Stenden South Africa and provides an excellent training for students. The hotel provides real-world learning environment. V. In all 3 years of study, students are exposed to the different practical aspects of the hospitality industry such as working of service areas, food production and service, conference planning, organising and execution.
6.4.3 Internship

I. A twenty-one week industrial placement during third year exposes students to working at a managerial level within their specific area of interest from a boutique hotel, to a cruise liner, event management company or private game lodge. II. One of the highlights offered by Stenden is the Grand Tour, which offers students the opportunity to travel while completing the degree; and III. In their second or third year, students have the opportunity to study a module or semester at one of the other campus sites: the Netherlands, Thailand, Indonesia or Qatar.
5. Crawford Cabins Tourism Stakeholder engagement session
1. Briefing by Wild Coast Tourism Association (WCTA)

a) Impediments to the development of the Wild Coast Area: I. The lack of infrastructure affects the influx of tourists. II. Poverty and unemployment. III. Lack of development. IV. Lack of capacity and resources in the local sphere of government; and V. Infrastructure
b) Service Delivery I. Access: Air and Road II. Signage III. Electricity IV. Communications V. Sewerage and waste disposal
c) Prioritisation I. N2 Resorts II. Community awareness III. Product development IV. Seasonality and staff education V. Institutional assistance
d) Unique Selling points I. Affordability II. Beach activities III. Adventure activities IV. Provincial Parks, Estuaries and cultural heritage

2. Key issues emanating from the engagement with tourism industry stakeholders I. Insufficient communication from national and provincial government with district and local municipalities with regard to tourism development. II. Lack of integrated approach to development. III. There was underdevelopment and little marketing of the existing attraction sites. IV. Poor infrastructure, infrastructure development and signage impacted on access to tourism products based in rural areas. V. Lack of coordinated effort and flow of information and stakeholders believe that there is a potential in the province but there is no flow of information. VI. Lack of clear roles and responsibilities of the different spheres of government in the development of tourism. VII. Cost of air tickets to the province are very expensive and there is a lack competition. VIII. High cost of attending Tourism Indaba these days than before. For example, a 3 x 3 metres stall use to cost R3 000. In 2012 the cost of the same space was R27 000. IX. Application for operating permit takes too long to be finalised. X. Tour Guides complain that it cost R800 to renew the certificate in every second year. XI. Zoning the Province need to rediscover the 9 nodes. XII. The grading system by Tourism Grading Council is expensive and did not offer any marketing benefits. XIII. Tourism Levy: the stakeholders indicated willingness to pay the levy, but also wanted to receive benefit from the fee payment.
3. Submission by Coffee Shack on Barriers to Entry and Alternatives to Grading System

I. To encourage entrepreneurs and micro-start ups in the tourism sector, particularly in disadvantaged areas, there must be as few barriers to entry as possible. II. Any grading or certification is another barrier to entry as it involves time to fill out the paper work, money to pay for the grading assessment. The current system penalises remote and rural areas, as they have to pay more for transport of the assessor.

III. The argument that tourists need to know the standard and quality of a product is not sustainable as in most destinations in the world, there is no system of standard or grading, yet tourists keep returning to those destinations, many of which receive many tourists than South Africa.
IV. The tourists use the previous methods of finding out which businesses are good and which are bad.

V. The way customers and tourists and the world is evolving, it would be better for South African tourism industry to be ahead of the international tourism industry and be one of the fore runners of the new consumer driven ratings and grading system, as the United Kingdom is doing.

VI. All the money, energy and time spent on having and maintaining a grading system in South Africa, could be used more effectively on transforming the tourism industry and also assisting the previously disadvantaged communities.

VII. It has become common knowledge that both business and government agree that there is too much red tape, paper work, regulation in South Africa, which stifles entrepreneurs and small businesses. This is further acknowledged by the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) and National Planning Commission and many other parties. Grading is one more unnecessary barrier to entry. It must not be made to become compulsory.
4. Briefing by the MEC of Economic Development and Environmental Affairs on infrastructure, skills development and tourism

I. According to the Hon. MEC the focus for the next few years must be to unlock the potential of the Eastern Cape while addressing simultaneously challenges in the economy and the environment. The province believed that the emphasis must primarily be to facilitate, develop and support the local.

II. The MEC indicated that the budget of the department will go down by 15 percent, but in real terms it will go down by 20 to 30 percent. As a result, there is a need for creatively mobilising the resources outside government for development.

III. The primary issue that is a serious challenge to the province is the infrastructure and the competing needs. Infrastructure development required a different thinking. Hence, the Government view was to declare the Wild Coast as a corridor.

IV. The Province requested the Committee to engage South African Airways (SAA) on the issue of Airlift strategy to align air transport with other national strategies through common criteria of the national interest. It was highlighted that the flower industry in the province had to die because harvested flowers could not reach the destination (London) on the same day.

V. The health of auto sector, a leading manufacturing industry, remains critical in the province. There are opportunities to broaden and deepen automotive component manufacturing under DTIs Automotive Production Development Programme.

VI. The province intend to accelerate companies access to the DTIs Manufacturing Competitive Enhancement Programme, to extend the provincial industrial jobs stimulus fund, and support additional proposals to the Development Bank of Southern Africa (DBSA) jobs fund.

VII. In addition to the focus on upgrading economic infrastructure, the plan also aims to improve the ability to support the retention of existing industrial jobs, stimulate new jobs in priority sectors, build social economy and improve skills development processes.

VIII. Manufacturing sector is responding well to these initiatives, and is known on what skills it requires. However, the challenge is the tourism sector because is not coordinated. There is a need to focus on training for tourism. The cluster approach appears to be working better.
7. Findings / Observations
The Committee made the following observations during the oversight:

XII. Rural tourism development remains a challenge. Government departments should tailor responses to this challenge in terms of programmes and budgets to address disparities and in an aligned programme to optimise actions that would cushion the vulnerable groups.

XIII. To ensure that the current EPWP Programmes are sustainable, they should be closely monitored and evaluated. This would assist in addressing concerns raised by the Auditor General in the 2010/11 financial year; including the difficulties of obtaining information specifically the statistics on the number of jobs created and the effectiveness or impact of the EPWP projects run by Department of Tourism on behalf of the communities.
XIV. There is no overlap of roles where the marketing of tourism locally and internationally is concerned.
XV. The support the different enterprises receive from the Department and how many of these enterprises actually yield positive results from this support is not clearly demonstrated.

XVI. Refocus on heritage and cultural heritage projects there was a greater need for investment towards cultural and heritage tourism. Heritage and cultural sites should be kept at an acceptable tourism level. The refocus on such sites would benefit poor rural communities.

XVII. The importance of road signage to tourists is often underestimated. Local government tourist road signage is extremely limited. It is also difficult to understand many of the historical sites of the township without a guide given the lack of interpretive boards.
XVIII. There is often breakdown in communication between local, provincial and national spheres with regards to the permissions and standards in tourism signage.

XIX. The linkages both ways on tourism related issues between national, provincial and local spheres are weak. There needs to be improved working relationships on tourism-related issues between municipalities and regional stakeholders through collaborative alliances.

XX. There is a need for a defined tourism support package (resources, funding and capacity) to support local government. Resources to assist and direct investment at local government to realise tourism opportunities. A knowledge and exchange platform to highlight best practice case studies from other municipalities to encourage peer-to- peer learning.

XXI. Tourism features very low on the priority outputs of the local municipalities due to priority needs such as water, electricity, infrastructure, housing sport and recreation. As a result, municipalities regard tourism as an unfunded mandate placed on local government.

XXII. The current lack of specific budget allocation towards the development of tourism at local government level is a challenge and results in low impact projects, unsustainable initiatives, and wish lists instead of action plans.
8. Recommendations
Based on the stakeholder engagements, submissions by provincial authorities and site visits and the common challenges identified, the committee recommends as follows:

XV. Public-Private Partnerships (PPPs): The Department should double its efforts by ensuring that the notion of private-public partnerships is a well endorsed practice for building capacity to delivery in the tourism and hospitality sectors. XVI. Small, Medium and Micro Enterprises (SMMEs): All spheres of government should work towards strengthening competitiveness and promotion of SMMEs and cooperatives as they remain the cornerstone for growth of the economy and creation of work opportunities within the tourism and hospitality sectors.
XVII. The Department needs to facilitate market access and entry into the value chain by small businesses and cooperatives and reduce regulatory burden on small businesses.

XVIII. Local Government: The local sphere of government is an important contributor to the success of tourism activities in terms of community driven tourism philosophy. The efforts should be coordinated within the provincial tourism growth strategy.

XIX. Job creation at local level: tourism is a demand-driven sector. Therefore the volume and value of demand inform investment in supply and job creation. Provision of public infrastructure supporting local economic development is improved. This will assist municipalities to focus Local Economic Development initiatives that are skills creating, employment generating and domestic production and consumption promoting.

XX. Signage and road infrastructure: poor road signage and infrastructure impact negatively on access to tourism products, especially in rural areas. The co-operative work between the Department of Tourism and the Department of Transport to be intensified.
XXI. Tourism information: Public education, awareness and information dissemination should be linked to outreach initiatives of the Department.
XXII. Synergic linkages should be developed and harnessed at all spheres of government so as to promote local tourism activities and strategic partnerships.

XXIII. Transformation of the tourism sector: There should greater action taken to support and implement Broad-Based Black Economic Empowerment (BBBEE) as well as procurement policy implemented to achieve the BBEEE imperatives of government.

XXIV. Air Lift Strategy: Aligning air transport with other national strategies through the common criteria of the national interest through interdepartmental participation with regards to National Foreign Policy, National Trade and Industry Strategy as well as general infrastructure requirements of South Africa. Reduced total cost of travel to South Africa should be the central focus of the strategy.

XXV. Skills Development: while the committee acknowledges the initiatives taken by the department to engage five universities in the country to develop skills and capacity the industry, there is also a need to support FET colleges and Sector Education and Training Authorities to be linked to business, industry and other advanced education and training programmes.
XXVI. Cost of air travel: Travel by air to Eastern Cape Province is too expensive. There is a need for national government to assist to increase number of flights and reduce cost of flights.

XXVII. Implementation of infrastructure development: Parliament should prioritise overseeing the implementation of infrastructure development aligned to rural communities and also ascertain support facilities in rural areas for tourism sector. XXVIII. Extended Public Works Programme: There should be greater focus on monitoring the outputs and outcomes of Extended Public Work Programmes as it holds potential for poverty relief and providing first level skills and opportunity for productive citizenry.
10. Appreciation

The committee would like to extend the special appreciation to MEC in the Province, Committees of Provincial Legislature, Executive Mayors, Provincial Head of Department, municipal managers, project managers and all the officials who provided support throughout the provincial oversight trip.

11. Conclusion The importance of intergovernmental relations and cooperative governance is of paramount importance for the growth of tourism in the country. There is a need for the Tourism National Strategy to be filtered down to municipal level in order to promote growth in the tourism sector. In as much as the Department has been instrumental in developing world class strategies and guidelines to promote tourism in the country; these strategies have not been implemented and if implemented in it is not in their entirety. In essence alignment of the three spheres remains a challenge. The geographic spread of tourism remains a major challenge especially in rural areas and successful growth in this area has an ability to translate positively towards transformation figures in the sector. In the same vein, it is important to engender a culture of innovation and that can only come about if space is created for an integrated approach involving feedback from the municipalities and other stakeholders.
Report to be considered.

debateSection.heading: REPORTS AND FINANCIAL STATEMENTS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF MINERAL RESOURCES AND THE REPORT OF THE AUDITOR-GENERAL ON THE 2010/11 FINANCIAL YEAR, DATED 22 AUGUST 2012
debateSection.p: 1. Introduction

The Committee on Public Accounts (the Committee) heard evidence on and considered the contents of the Annual Report and the Report of the Auditor- General (AG) on the 2010/11 financial statements of the Department of Mineral Resources (the Department). The Committee noted the qualified audit opinion, highlighted areas which required the attention of the Accounting Officer, and reports as follows:
2. Receivables for departmental revenue
The Auditor-General identified the following:

a) The receivables for departmental revenue balance of R72,2 million (2010: R72,5 million) included in disclosure note 24 to the financial statements, is misstated as a result of omissions in respect of payments received and not recorded, amounts due not being raised and incorrect interest calculations on outstanding balances. The Department did not identify and correct all the errors that exist in the balance as a result the extent of the error cannot be determined. The Departments records did not allow for the performance of alternative audit procedures to satisfy the Auditor-General of the receivables for departmental revenue. Consequently, there was insufficient appropriate audit evidence to satisfy the Auditor-General as to the existence, completeness, valuation and allocation of and rights pertaining to the receivables for departmental revenue balance.
The Committee recommends that the Accounting Officer ensures that:

a) The Department implements a system to assist in the accounting for these transactions, and the system should automatically calculate the outstanding balances at financial year end, including the correct interest for the period; b) Schedules are reviewed on a monthly basis to ensure the information captured is accurate and complete; and c) Officials responsible for capturing payments and keeping records should be held accountable for these omissions.
3. Revenue
The Auditor-General identified the following:

a) The Department could not provide sufficient appropriate audit evidence to support journal entries of R50.4 million debited to revenue. The journal entries were based on total receipts from royalty debtors without reconciling the payments received to outstanding debt balances thereby understating the revenue amount. Further, the credit entries in the revenue account include receipts from prospecting fees that have not been appropriately reconciled to outstanding receivables balances. There were no satisfactory alternative audit procedures that could be performed to obtain reasonable assurance that all revenue was properly recorded. Consequently, sufficient appropriate audit evidence was not obtained to satisfy the auditors as to the completeness, accuracy and classification of revenue of R30.3 million.
The Committee recommends that the Accounting Officer ensures that:

a) The journal entries are scrutinised to identify the amounts that have been incorrectly journalised; b) The incorrect entries representing revenue funds that have already been surrendered and amounts sourced from the receivables schedules are reversed; and c) Officials responsible for journal entries and record keeping be held accountable for lack of audit evidence for journal entries 4. Payables
The Auditor- General reported the following:

a) Due to the limitations identified under Revenue, the Auditor-General was unable to conclude on the existence, completeness, valuation and allocation of and obligations pertaining to the payables balance to the amount of R53,5 million. The Departments records did not permit the application of alternative audit procedures regarding the payables balances.
The Committee recommends that the Accounting Officer ensures that:

a) The journal entries are scrutinised to identify the amounts that have been incorrectly journalised; b) The incorrect entries representing revenue funds that have already been surrendered and amounts sourced from the receivables schedules are reversed; and c) Officials responsible for journal entries and record keeping be held accountable for lack of audit evidence for journal entries.
5. Provisions
The Auditor-General identified the following:

a) Included in note 29, impairments and other provisions, to the financial statements are receivables for departmental receivables revenue debt balances that are outstanding for longer than three years amounting to R36,3 million (2010: R36,5 million), which the department impairs in accordance with its policy on impairments. Sufficient appropriate audit evidence could not be obtained to conclude on the existence, completeness, valuation and allocation and obligations of the other provisions balance due to the limitation reported in receivables for departmental revenue debt balance.
The Committee recommends that the Accounting Officer ensures that:

a) The Department implements a system to assist in the accounting for these transactions, and the system should automatically calculate the outstanding balances at financial year end, including the correct interest for the period; b) Schedules are reviewed on a monthly basis to ensure the information captured is accurate and complete; and c) Officials responsible for journal entries and record keeping be held accountable for lack of audit evidence for journal entries.
6. Contingent liabilities
The Auditor-General identified the following:

a) The contingent liabilities, as disclosed in note 19 to the financial statements, include the Departments obligations in respect of abandoned mines. The Department is and has been conducting rehabilitation activities in respect of abandoned mined in accordance with the National Strategy for the Management of Derelict and Ownerless Mines in South Africa. The Department is still in the process of establishing a financial estimate of the liability with the result that management has taken a decision not to disclose a provision in this regard. The Departments records did not permit the application of alternative audit procedures regarding its obligation in respect of abandoned mines. Consequently, there was insufficient appropriate audit evidence to satisfy the Auditor-General as to the existence, completeness and valuation of the contingent liabilities and the corresponding impact on the provisions balance.
The Committee recommends that the Accounting Officer ensures that:

a) Management develops a methodology that will assist in identifying accounting estimates and valuation approaches suitable for assessing environmental liability; b) Significant judgements and estimates that are developed are documented and supported by verifiable source information; and c) Officials responsible for journal entries and record keeping be held accountable for lack of audit evidence for journal entries.
7. Conclusion

The Committee on Public Accounts recommends that the Executive Authority submits a progress report on the implementation of the above recommendations to the National Assembly within 60 days after the adoption of this report by the House.
The Committee on Public Accounts further recommends that the Accounting Officer submits quarterly reports on all the above-mentioned recommendations. Report to be considered.
